key_issues: The plaintiffs are seeking relief of permanent injunction restraining the defendant from infringing their trademark and passing off goods as their own.
The defendant has entered a belated written statement, seeking condonation of delay under Order VIII Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.
The court must determine whether the replication filed by the plaintiff is within the permissible time limit under Chapter VII Rule 5 of the Delhi High Court (Original Side) Rules, 2018.

The calculation of the time period for filing the replication is disputed, with the defendant arguing it should be counted from the date the written statement was supplied, and the plaintiff arguing it should be counted from the date the written statement was permitted to be taken on record.
The applicability of judgments in Ram Sarup Lugani v. Nirmal Lugani and Atlanta Limited v. National Highways & Infrastructure Development Corporation Limited to the present case is in question.
The court must consider the provisions of Order VIII Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, regarding the filing of a written statement and the condonation of delay.
The plaintiff's trademark rights and the alleged infringement by the defendant are central to the case, with the plaintiff seeking to protect their intellectual property.
The role of the Local Commissioner in seizing and inventoring infringing goods is also relevant to the case, as is the ex parte ad interim injunction granted against the defendant.
The interpretation of Chapter VII Rule 5 of the Delhi High Court (OS) Rules, 2018, and its application to the filing of the replication, is a key issue in the case.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary: SNS Products Private Limited vs. Ijaz Uddin**

**Background:**
The plaintiff, SNS Products Private Limited, filed a suit against the defendant, Ijaz Uddin, seeking relief of permanent injunction, restraining the defendant from infringing the plaintiff's trademark, passing off his goods as that of the plaintiff, damages, and other ancillary reliefs. The plaintiff alleged that the defendant was using the impugned mark 'SHAN E DELHI', 'SHAN-A-DELHI' or any other mark identical or deceptively similar to the plaintiff's trademark 'SHAN-E-DELHI'.

**Procedural History:**
The court granted an ex parte ad interim injunction against the defendant on January 17, 2022, restraining him from using the impugned mark. A Local Commissioner was appointed to seize and inventorize the infringing goods. The defendant entered appearance on April 26, 2022, and filed a written statement, which was belatedly filed with an application seeking condonation of delay of 27 days. The application was allowed by the Joint Registrar on July 11, 2022. The plaintiff filed a replication on July 23, 2022.

**Legal Issues:**
The defendant contended that the replication could not be taken on record as it was filed beyond the maximum permissible period of 45 days from the date when the written statement was supplied to the plaintiff. The defendant relied on Chapter VII Rule 5 of the Delhi High Court (Original Side) Rules, 2018, and two judgments: Ram Sarup Lugani v. Nirmal Lugani (2020) and Atlanta Limited v. National Highways & Infrastructure Development Corporation Limited (2019).

**Arguments:**
The plaintiff argued that the copy of the written statement was supplied to him only on May 17, 2022, and the time for counting the period for filing replication could only be counted from the date when the written statement was permitted to be taken on record, which was July 11, 2022. The plaintiff submitted that the judgments relied upon by the defendant were not applicable to the facts and circumstances of the case.

**Court Findings:**
The court found that the issue before the Division Bench in Ram Sarup Lugani (supra) was not regarding the date from which the period of 45 days for filing the replication would begin, but rather whether delay in filing the replication could be condoned beyond the period of 45 days in terms of Rule 5 of Chapter VII of the Delhi High Court (OS) Rules. Therefore, the observations of the Division Bench would not be of any assistance to the defendant.

**Decision:**
The court did not agree with the submission of the defendant that in all cases, the period for filing replication would commence from the date when the written statement was supplied to the plaintiff. The court's decision on the admissibility of the replication and the subsequent proceedings in the case are not explicitly stated in the provided text, as the decision page is not included. However, based on the court's findings, it appears that the court is inclined to allow the replication to be taken on record, as the defendant's contention regarding the timing of the replication is not supported by the applicable rules and judgments.

I do not agree with the submission of the defendant that in all cases
the period for filing replication would commence from the date of written
statement being supplied by the defendant to the plaintiff in terms of Rule 5
of the Delhi High Court (OS) Rules. Undoubtedly, the language used in
Rule 5 of the Delhi High Court (OS) Rules is that the replication has to be
filed within 30 days from the receipt of the written statement. This may be
ordinarily so. However, where the written statement was filed beyond the
statutory time limit and was taken on record only upon an application for
condonation of delay being allowed by the Court, the aforesaid rule has to
be interpreted in a manner that the period of 30 days will begin from the
time the written statement is permitted to be taken on record.

There would be no requirement for the plaintiff to file a replication in the
event that the application seeking condonation of delay in filing written

in delay is allowed and the written statement is taken on record. Therefore, it
is axiomatic that the period for filing replication would only commence from
the date when the delay is condoned and the written statement is taken on
record.

judgment in Atlanta Limited (supra). In the said case, the written statement

permitted to be taken on record only on a subsequent date and the replication

the judgment in Atlanta Limited (supra) is misplaced.

According to the PDF document "14. SNS PRODUCTS PRIVATE VS. IJAZ UDDIN.pdf", a legal proceeding is underway in the High Court of Delhi. The case, CS(COMM) 34/2022, involves SNS Products Private Limited as the plaintiff and Ijaz Uddin as the defendant. The court, presided over by Hon'ble Mr. Justice Amit Bansal, is considering a suit filed by the plaintiff seeking relief of permanent injunction.

The defendant argued that the plaintiff's replication was filed beyond the maximum permissible period of 45 days from the date when the written statement was supplied to the plaintiff. The defendant cited Chapter VII Rule 5 of the Delhi High Court (Original Side) Rules, 2018, and two judgments: Ram Sarup Lugani v. Nirmal Lugani (2020) and Atlanta Limited v. National Highways & Infrastructure Development Corporation Limited (2019).

The plaintiff countered that the written statement was supplied on May 17, 2022, and the time for filing replication should be counted from July 11, 2022, when the written statement was permitted to be taken on record. The plaintiff argued that the defendant's cited judgments are not applicable to the case.

The court considered the arguments and referred to Chapter VII Rule 5 of the Delhi High Court (OS) Rules, which states that replication should be filed within 30 days of receipt of the written statement. The court also considered the Division Bench's conclusion in Ram Sarup Lugani that Rule 5 is mandatory, and replication cannot be permitted after 45 days. The case is ongoing, with the court weighing the arguments and applicable rules. (Source: "14. SNS PRODUCTS PRIVATE VS. IJAZ UDDIN.pdf", Page 1-3 of 6)

tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "14. SNS PRODUCTS PRIVATE VS. IJAZ UDDIN.pdf", a legal case (CS(COMM) 34/2022) was heard in the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi. The plaintiff, SNS Products Private Limited, filed a suit against the defendant, Ijaz Uddin. The case revolves around the filing of a replication by the plaintiff, which the defendant objected to, citing a delay beyond the 45-day limit.

The court, presided over by Hon'ble Mr. Justice Amit Bansal, considered the defendant's submission that the 45-day period for filing the replication should commence from the date the written statement was supplied by the defendant to the plaintiff. However, the court disagreed, stating that the period should begin from the date the written statement was permitted to be taken on record, which was after the delay was condoned by the court.

The plaintiff filed the replication within 12 days of the written statement being taken on record, which was deemed timely. The defendant's reliance on the judgment in Atlanta Limited was deemed misplaced, as the facts of the two cases differed. Ultimately, the court permitted the replication to be taken on record, finding no merit in the defendant's submission. The case was listed for further proceedings on March 2, 2023, with interim orders to continue. Source: "14. SNS PRODUCTS PRIVATE VS. IJAZ UDDIN.pdf" (2023/DHC/000970, CS(COMM) 34/2022).

application of the plaintiff for taking the written statement off the record was
dismissed. The said application was rejected by the Court. In the present
case the written statement though filed by the defendant earlier, was
permitted to be taken on record only on a subsequent date and the replication
was filed within 12 days from the said date. Therefore, reliance placed on
the judgment in Atlanta Limited (supra) is misplaced.
15.
Therefore, I do not find any merit in the submission of the defendant
that the replication filed by the plaintiff along with admission/denial of
documents not be taken on record. Accordingly, the replication is permitted
be taken on record.
16.
List on 2nd March, 2023.
